articles.content:
Researchers Discover a New Phase of Ice by Squeezing Water Between Diamonds
The new form, called Ice XXI, appeared at room temperature in the lab, and it may have a similar density to ice on distant moons in our solar system
When someone talks about frozen water, they typically mean the ice cubes in a cold drink or the vast glaciers in Earth’s coldest corners. What most people don’t know, however, is that H2O molecules can arrange themselves into many different types, or phases, of ice with various structures. Researchers have discovered more than 20 of these phases, the latest of which—called Ice XXI—a team recently created under extreme pressure, allowing water to turn to ice at room temperature.
“The behavior of water under pressure may seem fantastical compared with the familiar liquid in our drinking glasses,” Jonas Sellberg, a physicist at the KTH Roal Institute of Technology in Sweden, who was not involved in the recent research, writes for Nature Materials. The discoveries show that “the landscape of the phases of water contains hidden valleys that are accessible via dynamic pathways.”
Familiar ice represents only a small fraction of frozen water’s forms, while researchers have created the rest in labs. These phases don’t occur naturally—on Earth, at least, reports Scientific American’s Meghan Bartels. But some of them might exist on other cosmic bodies, which explains why researchers are bothering to investigate these strange ices.
“Understanding the formation and transition pathways of the diverse H2O phases has been of interest in high-pressure physics and the search for life in space and on icy moons for a century,” writes the team that discovered Ice XXI in an October paper published in Nature Materials.
Did you know? The solar system’s icy moons
Astronomers think that a handful of icy moons in our solar system may have liquid water oceans beneath their frozen crusts. According to NASA, these six moons are Jupiter’s Callisto, Ganymede and Europa; Saturn’s Titan and Enceladus; and Neptune’s Triton.
Liquid water can crystallize, or turn into a solid, in a wide variety of situations, depending on the temperature and pressure. For example, water at room temperature turns into “Ice VI” when it experiences pressure higher than 0.96 gigapascals (GPa).
In the recent study, researchers used a tool called a dynamic diamond anvil cell (dDAC), which squeezes materials between two diamonds, producing intense amounts of pressure. Their dDAC created supercompressed water, which stayed liquid at room temperature despite the high pressure of more than 2 GPa.
As the dDAC compressed and decompressed the water, the team documented the water’s crystallization with X-ray lasers, capturing an image one million times per second. They discovered a number of complex crystallization pathways that researchers hadn’t known existed at room temperature, and they found the water transitioned through a new ice phase, Ice XXI, on its way to crystallizing as Ice VI.
“Looking at things at a very, very fast rate allows us to observe weird and wonderful phenomena,” Ashkan Salamat, a physicist at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, who was not involved in the study, tells Scientific American.
Ice’s crystal structure consists of repeating unit cells—and in the case of Ice XXI, its unit cell is notably large and intricate, looking like a rectangular prism with a square-shaped base.
On Earth, Ice XXI seems to be just a fleeting appearance in lab experiments, so far. But interestingly, “the density of Ice XXI is comparable to the high-pressure ice layers inside the icy moons of Jupiter and Saturn,” lead author Yun-Hee Lee, a researcher at the Korea Research Institute of Standards and Science, explains in a statement. “This discovery may provide new clues for exploring the origins of life under extreme conditions in space.”

articles.content:
Anthropologists Recover DNA of Syphilis-Causing Bacterium Relative From 5,500-Year-Old Human Remains, the Earliest Ever Found
The findings represent the oldest complete set of genetic information from this bacterial group and shed light on its evolutionary history
The origins of syphilis, a disfiguring disease first recorded when outbreaks swept across Europe in the late 1400s, have remained mysterious for centuries. Scientists have debated whether the bacterium that causes the disease, a form of Treponema pallidum, was circulating there long before the epidemic, or if it hopped aboard ships from the Americas during Christopher Columbus’s early trips.
Past research has recovered the bacterium’s DNA from the remains of people who lived in the Americas centuries before Columbus’s time. But new findings have just pushed the genetic record even further back—by a lot.
Analyses of bones from a man who lived 5,500 years ago in what’s now Colombia revealed that he carried a strain of T. pallidum, and researchers were able to put together its complete set of DNA, or genome. The work, published January 22 in the journal Science, provides a new window into the bacterium’s evolution and how it spread.
The findings “show there’s this long evolutionary history of treponemal pathogens that was already diversifying in the Americas thousands of years earlier than previously known,” says study co-author Elizabeth Nelson, a molecular anthropologist and paleopathologist at Southern Methodist University, in a statement.
Syphilis, primarily a sexually transmitted infection, is one of four main human treponemal diseases, which are caused by bacteria within the genus Treponema. T. pallidum is a spiral-shaped bacterium, and its various subspecies lead to three different diseases: syphilis, yaws and bejel. The fourth disease, pinta, is possibly caused by another subspecies or T. carateum.
Did you know? Syphilis prevalence
The World Health Organization estimates that about 8 million people ages 15 to 49 acquired syphilis in 2022. Many infected people don’t notice symptoms, but the disease can be diagnosed through testing.
Syphilis, yaws and bejel sometimes leave marks on bones at certain stages of disease. Most early genomes of T. pallidum have been recovered from skeletons that showed clear signs of infection. But the newly described remains, which came from a rock shelter in the Bogotá savanna in central Colombia, lacked the telltale marks.
The bacterium’s discovery happened “totally by chance,” study co-author Lars Fehren-Schmitz, an anthropologist at the University of California, Santa Cruz, tells Scientific American’s Emma Gometz.
Fehren-Schmitz and his colleagues were cataloguing ancient DNA to study human population history, per the statement. But analysis of one of the Colombian man’s tibias, or a shin bone, revealed that the individual carried a strain of T. pallidum.
After piecing together the bacterium’s genome, the researchers compared it with other known modern and historical T. pallidum DNA. That revealed that the 5,500-year-old strain appeared way earlier than any of its known subspecies, suggesting that treponemal diseases were more diverse thousands of years ago than they are currently, study co-author Nasreen Broomandkhoshbacht, a geneticist at the University of Vermont, tells Scientific American.
Although the recovered strain doesn’t match any previously known versions of T. pallidum, it’s closely related. A genetic analysis hinted that the ancient form diverged from other lineages around 13,700 years ago. For comparison, the three modern subspecies diverged just 6,000 years ago.
The new work “points to co-evolution of Treponema—not just the treponematosis [treponemal diseases], but the Treponema genus—with humans older than previously suspected,” Fernando González-Candelas, a geneticist at the University of Valencia in Spain who was not involved in the study, tells Scientific American.
Moreover, the new insights into T. pallidum’s origins could be socially important. People tend to make moral judgements about those living with syphilis, which can be a barrier to treatment, and linking the disease to a geographic location can reinforce stigma “by assigning blame to specific communities,” write Molly Zuckerman and Lydia Bailey, anthropologists at Mississippi State University who also weren’t involved in the research, in an accompanying commentary in Science.
But the study may help move conversations beyond a location of origin, they add. “Reframing syphilis, alongside other infectious diseases, as products of both localized and highly specific evolutionary, ecological and biosocial conditions and globalization may represent critical steps toward reducing stigma and improving public health.”

The American Southwest’s Iconic Joshua Trees Are Blooming Early—and Scientists Want Your Help to Figure Out Why
The spiky desert succulents typically blossom beginning in late February. But this season, many started growing flowers up to four months early
Joshua trees in the American Southwest are blooming early, a concerning development that scientists fear could affect the survival of the iconic desert plants and their pollinator partners.
Primarily found in the Mojave Desert, which spans parts of California, Nevada, Arizona and Utah, the Joshua tree is a unique, slow-growing succulent known for its spiky leaves and twisting, branching structure. These plants, which are members of the agave family, usually max out at 40 feet tall and are estimated to live around 150 years, on average.
To reproduce, Joshua trees typically unfurl clusters of white flowers from their branches and await the arrival of yucca moths, which are about the size of a grain of rice and the only species that can pollinate their blossoms. After the moths flit from flower to flower, the trees produce fleshy, light-green fruits filled with seeds, which rodents and other desert-dwelling critters help disperse across the landscape.
Normally, this process kicks off in late February. But this season, many Joshua trees started blooming in late October and November.
To track what’s happening—and the possible repercussions—scientists are asking members of the public for help. They’re calling on nature lovers in the Southwest to snap photos of any flowering or fruiting Joshua trees they see, then upload the images to the citizen science platform iNaturalist. Ideally, photo-snappers will return to the same trees multiple times, so that researchers can track the plants as the season progresses.
Something similar happened in the fall of 2018, but in that instance, the early-blossoming trees were mostly confined to the trees’ southernmost range. This time around, however, trees appear to be blooming early throughout the desert, says Jeremy Yoder, a biologist at California State University, Northridge, who put out the public call for help, to SFGate’s Erin Rode.
Scientists are still trying to understand exactly why the plants are growing flowers early, and combining new observations with 2018 data might help. But in the meantime, they’re concerned about the potential consequences of the out-of-season blooms.
“The real question when the trees flower super early like this is: Are the moths going to show up?” Yoder tells SFGate. “And what I think we’re seeing so far is that they’re not.”
The yucca moth and the Joshua tree have evolved to become entirely dependent upon each other for survival—a rare example of what scientists call “obligate mutualism.”
Mature yucca moths lay their eggs in Joshua tree blooms, a process that also helps transfer pollen from one plant to another. Their eggs later hatch inside the fruits, where the caterpillars feast upon some of the seeds. Eventually, the moths-to-be eat their way out of the fruits, burrow into the soil below and wrap themselves in cocoons. Nestled safely underground for the winter, they wait for the Joshua tree to start flowering again. Then, they emerge as adults and start the cycle all over again.
But this season’s early bloom might disrupt this carefully orchestrated timeline, putting both the moths and the Joshua trees at risk.
“Having absolute fidelity between host and pollinator works great so long as one species can count on the other to always be there ready and waiting,” wrote James W. Cornett, a desert ecologist who owns an ecological consulting firm, for Desert magazine in 2019. “But what happens when flower appearance and pollinator appearance get out of sync because, say, the flowers appear before the moths emerge from the soil?”
Scientists don’t fully understand the environmental triggers that prompt adult yucca moths to emerge from the dirt. But they suspect that the creatures use temperature as a cue—meaning they likely won’t be coming out now to pollinate the blooming Joshua trees, because it’s still too cold, Yoder says in a statement.
If the yucca moths aren’t around to pollinate the flowers, then the Joshua trees won’t produce fruit, which means no new seeds and no new trees. And the species needs to produce numerous seeds and trees because only a handful survive the 40 or more years it takes to mature—most get eaten by rodents, birds and rabbits, per Desert magazine.
Did you know? More threats to Joshua trees
The succulent species faces several other threats, including habitat loss and more frequent and intense wildfires, both of which result from climate change.
The call for citizen scientists’ observations of the early bloom might help scientists determine what prompted it, which they currently think was intense, late-season rains. The data could reveal geographic patterns, such as whether the early-flowering Joshua trees seem to be clustered in places that received lots of rain last fall.
“We want to see ... where the flowers are occurring, what the weather was like, and also if those flowers are resulting in any fruit,” says Kirsten Zornado, an ecologist at California State University, Northridge, in the statement.

What Happened to This 1,000-Pound Butter Sculpture After the Crowds Melted Away?
At the end of the 2026 Pennsylvania Farm Show, volunteers and students carefully dismantled the creamy masterpiece so it could be used to produce renewable energy for local homes
What do you do with a sculpture made from 1,000 pounds of butter once you no longer need it? Don’t throw it away—instead, dismantle the creamy masterpiece and use it to produce renewable energy for local homes.
That was the eco-friendly fate of the massive butter sculpture displayed at the Pennsylvania Farm Show this month, reports DaniRae Renno for the Patriot-News.
After the conclusion of the 2026 event, students with the 4-H Club of Dauphin County gathered inside the refrigerated display room at the Pennsylvania Farm Show Complex and Expo Center to carefully break down the sculpture.
Once they finished with their chilly work, the remnants were transported to Reinford Farms, a 1,100-acre dairy farm in neighboring Mifflintown. Owner Brett Reinford planned to chuck the butter into one of his anaerobic digesters, which help keep food waste out of landfills.
After about three or four hours in the digester, Reinford says the butter will be transformed into methane, which can then be used to provide electricity to nearby homes.
“Inside [the unit's] tank, there’s a process that converts the butter, as well as manure and other food waste, into methane,” Reinford tells WPMT’s Natalie Koranda. “We have specialized motors that run on methane and a generator that produces power.”
Quick facts: How cold was the butter sculpture kept?
- As the artists were creating the sculpture, the refrigerated display case was kept at around 55 degrees Fahrenheit.
- Once they finished, the temperature was dropped even lower to ensure the work of art remained intact for the duration of the week-long farm show.
It took just four hours to tear down this year’s sculpture so it could be recycled, reports WFMJ’s Camille Sipple. However, long before the farm show kicked off on January 10, Philadelphia-based food sculptors Jim Victor and Marie Pelton spent months working to bring the elaborate display to life, per WPMT’s Sedona Meadows.
They start their process by coming up with a general concept before moving on to a sketch of the design. Based on this drawing, the artists also build custom, welded metal structures to stabilize the gobs of butter. Then, they carefully shape donated “scrap” butter that’s not suitable for consumption into recognizable forms.
“It’s very unique what we do,” Pelton told USA Today’s Phaedra Trethan last year.
This year’s sculpture was called A Toast to Our Nation’s 250th Anniversary: Inspired by Founders. Grown by Farmers. The piece showed Benjamin Franklin and the founding fathers at the signing of the Declaration of Independence in Philadelphia in 1776. It also featured the Liberty Bell and Betsy Ross in honor of the nation’s birthday.
The sculpture was intended to reflect “how agriculture has been the roots of our nation’s growth and prosperity for 250 years, and how Pennsylvania farmers will continue to lead us forward,” according to a statement from Pennsylvania Agriculture Secretary Russell Redding.
The work was the 35th butter sculpture to debut at the farm show. Since 1991, organizers have commissioned artists to create elaborate, creamy-yellow masterpieces, depicting the likeness of people such as Franklin, World War II soldiers and cafeteria workers. These intricate butter sculptures have become a major highlight of the annual agricultural gathering, attracting crowds of fans at the state’s farm show complex in Harrisburg.
“It’s an honor to be part of the tradition every year,” Victor told the Patriot-News’ Sean Adams at the unveiling ceremony for the 2026 sculpture. “Especially for this commemorative year.”
